member.name: T:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.IStoredProcedureExecutionWrapper
member.summary: A wrapper interface around methods which execute stored procedures in SQL server, allowing those methods to be mocked in unit tests.

member.name: M:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.IStoredProcedureExecutionWrapper.Execute(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.SqlParameter})
member.summary: Executes a stored procedure which does not return a result set.
member.param: The name of the stored procedure.
The parameters to pass to the stored procedure.

member.name: T:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlCommandExecutionRetried
member.summary: Count metric which records execution of a SQL command resulting in a transient error and being retried.

member.name: T:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SessionDeadlockPriority
member.summary: Defines values for the SQL Server session deadlock priority setting.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SessionDeadlockPriority.Low
member.summary: Specifies that the current session will be more likely to be the deadlock victim (will be the victim in deadlocks where the other session has 'normal' or 'high' priority).

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SessionDeadlockPriority.Normal
member.summary: Specifies that the current session will be equally likely to be the deadlock victim (will be the victim in deadlocks where the other session has 'high' priority).

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SessionDeadlockPriority.High
member.summary: Specifies that the current session will be less likely to be the deadlock victim (will only potentially be the victim in deadlocks where the other session also has 'high' priority).

member.name: T:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4
member.summary: An implementation of and which persists access manager events in bulk to and allows reading of objects from a Microsoft SQL Server database.
member.typeparam: The type of users in the application managed by the AccessManager.
The type of groups in the application managed by the AccessManager.
The type of components in the application managed by the AccessManager.
The type of levels of access which can be assigned to an application component.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.stagingTable
member.summary: Staging table which is populated with all events from a Flush() operation before passing to SQL Server as a table-valued parameter. As this table is used to pass all events in a single operation, it contains generic columns holding the event data, the content of which varies according to the type of the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.idColumn
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds a sequential id for the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventTypeColumn
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds the type of the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventIdColumn
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds a unique id for the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventActionColumn
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds the action of the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.occurredTimeColumn
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds time that the event originally occurred.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.hashCodeColumn
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds hash code for the primary element of the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventData1Column
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds the first piece of data pertaining to the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventData2Column
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds the second piece of data pertaining to the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventData3Column
member.summary: Column in the staging table which holds the third piece of data pertaining to the event.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.eventTypeToStagingTablePopulationOperationMap
member.summary: Maps types (subclasses of ) to actions which populate a row in the staging table with details of an event of that type.

member.name: F:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.idColumnValue
member.summary: Holds the value to put in the 'Id' column in the staging table.

member.name: M:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.CreateEventTypeToStagingTablePopulationOperationMap
member.summary: Returns a dictionary mapping types (subclasses of ) to actions which populate a row in the staging table with details of an event of that type.
member.returns: A dictionary keyed by type, whose value is an action which accepts a subclass of (having the same type as the key), and a , and which populates the row with details of the event.
member.remarks: Traditionally, the 'switch' statement in C# was preferred to multiple 'if / else' as apparently the compiler was able to use branch tables to more quickly move to a matching condition within the statement (instead of having to iterate on average 1/2 the cases each time with 'if / else'). However since C# 7 we're now able to use non-equality / range / pattern conditions within the 'switch' statement. I haven't been able to find any documentation as to whether this has had a negative impact on performance (although difficult to see how it cannot have), however to mitigate I'm putting all the processing routines for different subclasses into a dictionary... hence the lookup speed should at least scale equivalently to the aforementioned branch tables.

member.name: M:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalBulkPersister`4.PopulateDataRowWithTemporalEventBufferItemBaseProperties(ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Models.TemporalEventBufferItemBase,System.Data.DataRow)

member.name: T:ApplicationAccess.Persistence.Sql.SqlServer.SqlServerAccessManagerTemporalPersister`4
member.summary: An implementation of and which persists access manager events to and allows reading of objects from a Microsoft SQL Server database.
member.typeparam: The type of users in the IAccessManagerTemporalEventPersister and IAccessManagerTemporalPersistentReader implementations.
The type of groups in the IAccessManagerTemporalEventPersister and IAccessManagerTemporalPersistentReader implementations.
The type of components in the IAccessManagerEventProcessor and IAccessManagerTemporalPersistentReader implementations.
The type of levels of access in the IAccessManagerTemporalEventPersister and IAccessManagerTemporalPersistentReader implementations.
member.remarks: Note that IAccessManagerEventProcessor methods implemented in this class should not be called from concurrent threads. The class is designed to operate behind a class which manages mutual exclusion such as the AccessManagerTemporalEventPersisterBuffer or ConcurrentAccessManagerEventValidator classes.
